prompt.p: A 39-year-old woman presents complaining of weight gain and change in menstrual cycle. On examination there is hair loss (male-pattern baldness), and thin skin with bruises. There is truncal obesity and proximal muscle atrophy. Her blood pressure is 141/85 mmHg.
What is most likely investigation to confirm the diagnosis?

modalFeedback.p: Option C is Correct. The patient has features of Cushing's syndrome due to excess production of corticosteroid. Dexamethasone a synthetic corticosteroid that would suppress corticosteroid releasing hormone and ACTH, causing cortisol secretion to fall. The test is positive if this response fails. A Synacthen ® test stimulates cortisol secretion and is used in Addison's disease. A catecholamine assay is used to test phaeochromocytoma. A desmopressin test is used in diabetes insipidus.
Option A is Incorrect. Used in diagnosis of phaeochromocytoma (an adrenal medulla neuroendocrine tumour). It can present as palpitations, headaches, hypertension, tachycardia and anxiety.
Option B is Incorrect. Used in diagnosis of diabetes inspidus. Characterized by polyuria and polydipsia.

Option D is Incorrect. Used to diagnose adrenal insufficiency or Addison's disease. Administration in a normal individual stimulates the adrenal cortex and results in cortisol increase, which is measured.
Option E is Incorrect. Used to diagnose hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism. The features of bruising and thin skin do not occur in thyroid disorders.
